p: Patients were enrolled in this study after they or their parents provided written informed consent. This study was approved by the institutional review board of Severance Hospital. Samples of congenital cholesteatoma and retroauricular skin were harvested from 6 male children between 4 and 5 year old. All congenial cholesteatomas presented as spherical epithelial pearls behind an intact eardrum in the anterior superior quadrant ( Fig 1). In all cases, the congenital cholesteatoma was removed from the middle ear cavity without damaging its capsule. The tympanomeatal flap was elevated using the retroauricular approach. A small amount of retroauricular skin (5 mm x 3 mm ellipsoid) was harvested as a control sample. Samples of acquired cholesteatomas in the pars flaccida area of tympanic membrane were also harvested from 2 adult patients during tympanomastoid surgery ( Table 1).
